title: Q2 Checkpoint: Congruence & Right Triangles
description: Cumulative assessment covering triangle congruence postulates (SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, HL), CPCTC, congruence proofs, Pythagorean Theorem and its converse, special right triangles, and introductory trig ratios.

assessmentProblems.question: Two triangles have three pairs of congruent sides. Name the congruence postulate.
In two right triangles, the hypotenuses are congruent and one pair of legs is congruent. Name the congruence theorem.
Explain why SSA is NOT a valid method for proving triangle congruence.
assessmentProblems.answer: SSA (two sides and a non-included angle) can produce two different triangles—the ambiguous case. The third side can 'swing' to two positions, creating different triangles with the same given information.

assessmentProblems.question: △ABC ≅ △XYZ by SAS. If AB = 14 and ∠A = 50°, find XY and ∠X.
A right triangle has legs of 8 and 15. Find the hypotenuse.
A triangle has sides 7, 24, and 25. Determine if it is a right triangle.
In a 45-45-90 triangle, the hypotenuse measures 18. Find the length of each leg.
In a 30-60-90 triangle, the side opposite the 60° angle is 5√3. Find the hypotenuse.
In a right triangle, the side opposite angle θ is 7 and the hypotenuse is 25. Find sin(θ) and cos(θ).
A surveyor stands 100 feet from the base of a building and measures the angle of elevation to the top as 40°. How tall is the building? (Round to the nearest foot. tan 40° ≈ 0.839)

answerKeys.q2-3: SSA can produce two different triangles (ambiguous case)
